presidents.name: Woodrow Wilson
presidents.summary: Progressive academic who led the United States through World War I and tried to build a liberal international order around the League of Nations.

cabinet.name: William Jennings Bryan (1913-1915); Robert Lansing (1915-1920); Bainbridge Colby (1920-1921)
cabinet.notes: Managed neutrality, then wartime diplomacy and the peace conference.

cabinet.name: Newton D. Baker
cabinet.notes: Oversaw Selective Service, American Expeditionary Forces buildup, and war mobilization.

cabinet.name: Josephus Daniels
cabinet.notes: Managed naval expansion and convoy operations.

events.description: Progressive reforms, Federal Reserve Act, and declared neutrality in the opening years of World War I.
Asked Congress for a declaration of war on Germany; mobilized the economy and raised the American Expeditionary Forces.
Issued the Fourteen Points, led the Paris Peace Conference, and advocated for the League of Nations.
Faced the First Red Scare and a Senate defeat of the Versailles Treaty after a national speaking tour and stroke.

presidents.name: Warren G. Harding
presidents.summary: Promised a return to normalcy after World War I, favored pro-business growth, and saw his administration rocked by scandals.

cabinet.name: Charles Evans Hughes
cabinet.notes: Led the Washington Naval Conference and normalized relations with Europe.

cabinet.name: Andrew Mellon
cabinet.notes: Championed tax cuts and debt reduction.

cabinet.name: Herbert Hoover
cabinet.notes: Coordinated trade expansion and disaster relief.

events.description: Budget and Accounting Act created the Bureau of the Budget and the General Accounting Office.
Washington Naval Conference set tonnage limits on capital ships and affirmed the Open Door in Asia.
Teapot Dome bribery scandal erupted over oil leases, tainting the administration even after Harding's death.

presidents.name: Calvin Coolidge
presidents.summary: Laissez-faire conservative who oversaw boom years, modest regulatory reforms, and restrained foreign policy involvement.

cabinet.name: Charles Evans Hughes (1923-1925); Frank B. Kellogg (1925-1929)
cabinet.notes: Negotiated the Dawes Plan and Kellogg-Briand Pact.

cabinet.name: Andrew Mellon
cabinet.notes: Maintained low taxes and budget surpluses.

cabinet.name: Herbert Hoover
cabinet.notes: Managed aviation, radio, and flood relief.

events.description: Johnson-Reed Immigration Act established national origins quotas.
Dawes Plan restructured German reparations with American banking support.
Great Mississippi Flood prompted federal relief debates.
Kellogg-Briand Pact renounced war as national policy.

presidents.name: Herbert Hoover
presidents.summary: Engineer turned humanitarian who struggled to confront the Great Depression with voluntary cooperation and limited federal aid.

cabinet.name: Henry L. Stimson
cabinet.notes: Asserted nonrecognition of Japanese conquest in Manchuria.

cabinet.name: Andrew Mellon (1929-1932); Ogden Mills (1932-1933)
cabinet.notes: Initially defended orthodox fiscal policy until late crisis.

cabinet.name: Patrick J. Hurley
cabinet.notes: Advocated preparedness amid global instability.

events.description: Stock market crash triggered the global Great Depression.
Smoot-Hawley Tariff provoked retaliatory trade restrictions.
Reconstruction Finance Corporation extended emergency credit to banks and railroads.
Bonus Army marchers were expelled from Washington by federal troops.

presidents.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt
presidents.vicePresident: John Nance Garner; Henry A. Wallace; Harry S. Truman
presidents.summary: Four-term leader who launched the New Deal, rearmed the nation, and steered the Allied coalition to victory in World War II.

cabinet.name: Cordell Hull (1933-1944); Edward Stettinius Jr. (1944-1945)
cabinet.notes: Led Good Neighbor policy and wartime alliance management.

cabinet.name: George Dern (1933-1936); Harry H. Woodring (1936-1940); Henry L. Stimson (1940-1945)
cabinet.notes: Oversaw mobilization and coalition warfare.

cabinet.name: William Woodin (1933-1934); Henry Morgenthau Jr. (1934-1945)
cabinet.notes: Financed New Deal and wartime spending.

events.description: First and Second New Deals created Social Security, the SEC, and labor protections while stabilizing banks.
Neutrality revisions, Lend-Lease, and the Arsenal of Democracy aided Allies prior to Pearl Harbor.
Led the United States during World War II in Europe and the Pacific, culminating in Yalta and the creation of the United Nations.

presidents.name: Harry S. Truman
presidents.summary: Finished World War II, launched the architecture of containment, and committed U.S. forces to Korea.

cabinet.name: Edward Stettinius Jr.; James F. Byrnes; George C. Marshall; Dean Acheson
cabinet.notes: Crafted the Marshall Plan, Truman Doctrine, and NATO.

cabinet.name: James Forrestal; Louis Johnson; George C. Marshall; Robert A. Lovett
cabinet.notes: Oversaw unification of the services and Korean War mobilization.

cabinet.name: Fred Vinson; John W. Snyder
cabinet.notes: Managed reconversion and postwar inflation.

events.description: Approved atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki and accepted Japan's surrender.
Truman Doctrine, Marshall Plan, Berlin Airlift, and NATO formalized containment.
Committed troops to the Korean War under UN command after North Korea's invasion.

presidents.name: Dwight D. Eisenhower
presidents.summary: Former Supreme Allied Commander who stabilized Cold War tensions with the New Look strategy and warned about the military-industrial complex.

cabinet.name: John Foster Dulles (1953-1959); Christian Herter (1959-1961)
cabinet.notes: Led brinkmanship diplomacy from Dien Bien Phu to the U-2 crisis.

cabinet.name: Charles Erwin Wilson; Neil McElroy; Thomas S. Gates Jr.
cabinet.notes: Implemented massive retaliation, SAC expansion, and early space programs.

cabinet.name: George M. Humphrey (1953-1957); Robert B. Anderson (1957-1961)
cabinet.notes: Maintained balanced budgets and a strong dollar.

events.description: Negotiated Korean War armistice and ended active combat.
Formed SEATO and backed the Formosa Resolution to defend Taiwan.
Handled the Suez Crisis while condemning Anglo-French intervention.
Sputnik shock spurred NASA, the National Defense Education Act, and ICBM development.

presidents.name: John F. Kennedy
presidents.summary: Cold War liberal who promoted the New Frontier, faced the most dangerous nuclear crisis, and set the moonshot goal before his assassination.

cabinet.name: Dean Rusk
cabinet.notes: Managed Berlin, Cuba, and early Vietnam decisions.

cabinet.name: Robert McNamara
cabinet.notes: Centralized Pentagon planning, flexible response, and Vietnam advisers.

cabinet.name: Robert F. Kennedy
cabinet.notes: Led civil rights enforcement and backchannel diplomacy during crises.

events.description: Bay of Pigs invasion failed, prompting distrust of CIA plans.
Cuban Missile Crisis resulted in Soviet missile withdrawal and a nuclear test ban push.
Accelerated U.S. advisory role in Vietnam and created the Green Berets build-up.
Launched the Alliance for Progress and Peace Corps in Latin America.

presidents.name: Lyndon B. Johnson
presidents.summary: Master legislator who delivered landmark civil rights and welfare laws while escalating the Vietnam War and facing domestic unrest.

cabinet.name: Dean Rusk
cabinet.notes: Backed escalation and diplomacy over Vietnam and the Dominican Republic.

cabinet.name: Robert McNamara (1963-1968); Clark Clifford (1968-1969)
cabinet.notes: Directed Rolling Thunder and troop surges.

cabinet.name: Douglas Dillon (1963-1965); Henry Fowler (1965-1968); Joseph Barr (1969)
cabinet.notes: Financed Great Society and war spending pressures.

events.description: Civil Rights Act and Voting Rights Act dismantled Jim Crow and empowered federal enforcement.
Great Society created Medicare, Medicaid, and antipoverty programs.
Vietnam War escalated with Operation Rolling Thunder and 500,000 U.S. troops, culminating in the Tet Offensive.
Intervened in the Dominican Republic to prevent a perceived communist takeover.

presidents.name: Richard Nixon
presidents.summary: Pragmatic strategist who ended the draft, opened relations with China, pursued detente, and resigned amid Watergate.

cabinet.name: William P. Rogers (1969-1973); Henry Kissinger (1973-1974)
cabinet.notes: Managed China opening, SALT I, and shuttle diplomacy.

cabinet.name: Melvin Laird; Elliot Richardson; James Schlesinger
cabinet.notes: Oversaw Vietnamization and the end of conscription.

cabinet.name: John N. Mitchell
cabinet.notes: Directed law-and-order agenda and was convicted for Watergate.

events.description: Vietnamization, Cambodia incursions, Paris Peace Accords, and POW withdrawals.
Ping-Pong diplomacy and the Shanghai Communique normalized ties with the PRC.
SALT I and the ABM Treaty formalized detente with the Soviet Union.
Watergate investigations exposed abuses, leading to resignation.

presidents.name: Gerald Ford
presidents.summary: Unelected president who emphasized transparency after Watergate while managing the end of the Vietnam War and stagflation.

cabinet.name: Henry Kissinger
cabinet.notes: Managed Helsinki Accords and Middle East shuttle diplomacy.

cabinet.name: James Schlesinger (1974-1975); Donald Rumsfeld (1975-1977)
cabinet.notes: Oversaw post-Vietnam recalibration and the Mayaguez rescue.

cabinet.name: Donald Rumsfeld; Dick Cheney
cabinet.notes: Coordinated domestic policy and relations with Congress.

events.description: Issued a pardon for Richard Nixon, prioritizing national healing.
Oversaw evacuation of Saigon and end of U.S. presence in Vietnam.
Helsinki Final Act advanced human rights monitoring across the Soviet bloc.
Mayaguez incident saw Marines rescue a seized merchant ship off Cambodia.

presidents.name: Jimmy Carter
presidents.summary: Georgia reformer who emphasized human rights, brokered Middle East peace, and struggled with stagflation and the Iran hostage crisis.

cabinet.name: Cyrus Vance (1977-1980); Edmund Muskie (1980-1981)
cabinet.notes: Pursued human rights diplomacy and SALT II; resigned over the Iran rescue.

cabinet.name: Harold Brown
cabinet.notes: Promoted stealth aircraft, naval expansion, and Rapid Deployment Force planning.

cabinet.name: Zbigniew Brzezinski
cabinet.notes: Championed normalization with China and the response to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan.

events.description: Camp David Accords produced peace between Egypt and Israel.
Established full diplomatic recognition of the People's Republic of China.
Iranian revolution and hostage crisis dominated foreign policy, culminating in a failed rescue mission.
SALT II signed with the Soviet Union but never ratified after the invasion of Afghanistan.

presidents.name: Ronald Reagan
presidents.summary: Conservative icon who pursued tax cuts, defense buildup, confrontational early Cold War posture, and later negotiated arms control with Moscow.

cabinet.name: Alexander Haig (1981-1982); George P. Shultz (1982-1989)
cabinet.notes: Managed Lebanon, INF Treaty, and thaw with Gorbachev.

cabinet.name: Caspar Weinberger (1981-1987); Frank Carlucci (1987-1989)
cabinet.notes: Directed defense buildup, SDI, and interventions in Grenada and Lebanon.

cabinet.name: William Clark; Robert McFarlane; John Poindexter; Frank Carlucci; Colin Powell
cabinet.notes: Coordinated Iran-Contra network and later reset policy.

events.description: Economic Recovery Tax Act launched Reaganomics and the Volcker disinflation.
Marine barracks bombing in Beirut led to withdrawal; Operation Urgent Fury ousted the Grenadian junta.
Iran-Contra affair revealed covert arms sales funding Nicaraguan rebels.
INF Treaty eliminated an entire class of nuclear missiles in Europe.

presidents.name: George H. W. Bush
presidents.summary: Experienced diplomat who managed the peaceful end of the Cold War and assembled a UN-backed coalition in the Gulf War.

cabinet.name: James A. Baker III (1989-1992); Lawrence Eagleburger (1992-1993)
cabinet.notes: Managed German reunification and multilateral diplomacy.

cabinet.name: Dick Cheney
cabinet.notes: Commanded Just Cause in Panama and Desert Storm.

cabinet.name: Colin Powell
cabinet.notes: Executed the Powell Doctrine in the Gulf.

events.description: Operation Just Cause removed Manuel Noriega in Panama.
Led Operation Desert Shield/Desert Storm to expel Iraq from Kuwait.
Managed fall of the Berlin Wall, Soviet collapse, and START I.
Faced recession and signed the 1990 Budget Enforcement Act raising taxes.

presidents.name: Bill Clinton
presidents.summary: New Democrat who balanced budgets, expanded trade, and used NATO power in the Balkans while surviving impeachment.

cabinet.name: Warren Christopher (1993-1997); Madeleine Albright (1997-2001)
cabinet.notes: Championed NATO enlargement and Kosovo intervention.

cabinet.name: Les Aspin; William Perry; William Cohen
cabinet.notes: Managed drawdowns, Bosnia, and Kosovo.

cabinet.name: Anthony Lake; Sandy Berger
cabinet.notes: Guided Haiti intervention and counterterror initiatives.

events.description: NAFTA ratified and the World Trade Organization launched.
Dayton Accords ended the Bosnian war under U.S. leadership.
Impeached over the Lewinsky scandal but acquitted by the Senate.
NATO air war over Kosovo forced Serbian withdrawal from Kosovo.

presidents.name: George W. Bush
presidents.summary: Led the United States through 9/11, launched the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and responded to Hurricane Katrina and the global financial crisis.

cabinet.name: Colin Powell (2001-2005); Condoleezza Rice (2005-2009)
cabinet.notes: Built the 9/11 coalition and later pursued freedom agendas.

cabinet.name: Donald Rumsfeld (2001-2006); Robert Gates (2006-2009)
cabinet.notes: Oversaw invasions and counterinsurgency surges.

cabinet.name: Paul O'Neill; John Snow; Henry Paulson
cabinet.notes: Managed tax cuts and the 2008 financial rescue.

events.description: Terrorist attacks led to the Global War on Terror and the invasion of Afghanistan.
Launched the Iraq War to depose Saddam Hussein, leading to long insurgency.
Hurricane Katrina exposed homeland security and disaster response failures.
Financial crisis triggered TARP bank rescues and recession.

presidents.name: Barack Obama
presidents.summary: Progressive pragmatist who passed the Affordable Care Act, ended combat operations in Iraq, targeted al-Qaeda, and pursued climate and Iran nuclear agreements.

cabinet.name: Hillary Clinton (2009-2013); John Kerry (2013-2017)
cabinet.notes: Managed the pivot to Asia, Libya intervention, and Iran talks.

cabinet.name: Robert Gates; Leon Panetta; Chuck Hagel; Ash Carter
cabinet.notes: Handled Afghanistan surge, ISIS campaign, and Syria debates.

cabinet.name: Eric Holder (2009-2015); Loretta Lynch (2015-2017)
cabinet.notes: Led civil rights enforcement and counterterror prosecutions.

events.description: Affordable Care Act overhauled health insurance coverage.
Ordered raid that killed Osama bin Laden and supported the NATO Libya campaign.
Iran nuclear deal (JCPOA) and Paris Climate Agreement were concluded.
Responded to ISIS with Operation Inherent Resolve and re-engaged in Iraq and Syria.

presidents.name: Donald Trump
presidents.summary: Nationalist populist who pursued tax cuts, tariff battles with China, conservative courts, and faced two impeachments during a pandemic.

cabinet.name: Rex Tillerson (2017-2018); Mike Pompeo (2018-2021)
cabinet.notes: Reoriented policy toward great-power competition and maximum pressure on Iran.

cabinet.name: Jim Mattis (2017-2018); Mark Esper (2019-2020); acting chiefs including Patrick Shanahan and Chris Miller
cabinet.notes: Managed ISIS fight, troop withdrawals, and civil-military tensions.

cabinet.name: Steven Mnuchin
cabinet.notes: Led 2017 tax cut implementation and pandemic relief lending facilities.

events.description: Tax Cuts and Jobs Act reduced corporate rates and reshaped the tax code.
Trade war with China imposed tariffs and renegotiated NAFTA into USMCA.
COVID-19 pandemic response combined travel bans, Operation Warp Speed, and contested public health guidance.
Abraham Accords normalized relations between Israel and several Arab states.

presidents.name: Joe Biden
presidents.summary: Veteran senator who prioritized pandemic recovery, rebuilding alliances, and confronting Russia and China.

cabinet.name: Antony Blinken
cabinet.notes: Coordinated NATO responses to Russia's invasion of Ukraine and Indo-Pacific strategy.

cabinet.name: Lloyd Austin
cabinet.notes: Managed Afghanistan withdrawal, Ukraine security assistance, and modernization.

cabinet.name: Janet Yellen
cabinet.notes: Implemented the American Rescue Plan, infrastructure financing, and global minimum tax talks.

events.description: American Rescue Plan and COVID-19 vaccination surge aimed to reopen the economy.
Completed the withdrawal from Afghanistan after the Taliban takeover.
Provided extensive aid to Ukraine and expanded NATO as Finland and Sweden sought membership.
CHIPS and Science Act plus Inflation Reduction Act invested in industrial policy and clean energy.

presidents.name: Donald Trump
presidents.summary: Returned to office as the 47th president with a second-term agenda centered on domestic renewal and a renewed America First foreign policy.

cabinet.name: Announcements pending
cabinet.notes: Cabinet-level appointments for the second term.

events.description: Inaugurated for a second term on January 20, 2025.
